source.body: This protocol uses 5/8 reagents per sample compared to the original LunaScript protocol.
A mastermix should be made up in the mastermix cabinet and aliquoted into PCR strip tubes. Tubes should be wiped down when entering and leaving the mastermix cabinet.

source.description:
Gently mix by pipetting and pulse spin the tube to collect liquid at the bottom of the tube.
Incubate the reaction as follows:
for

source.body: *Incubation for 20 min on 55 °C is used instead of 10 min of the kit protocol to make sure cDNA is synthesized efficiently. However, we have not confirmed the benefit of this modification, yet.

source.description:
If concentration of your primer stocks are 50 µM, generate primer pool stocks by adding each primers equally or as described in tables below to Eppendorf tubes labelled either “Pool 1 (50 µM)” or “Pool 2 (50 µM)”. These are your 50 µM stocks of each primer pool.
If concentration of the primer stocks are 100 µM, dilute this primer pool 1:1 in molecular grade water, to generate 50 µM primer stocks.
It is recommend that multiple aliquots of each primer pool are made to in case of degradation or contamination.

source.body: Primers should be diluted and pooled in the mastermix cabinet which should be cleaned with decontamination wipes and UV sterilised before and after use.

source.description:
In the mastermix hood set up the multiplex PCR reactions as follows in 0.2 mL 8-strip PCR tubes or 96-well PCR plate:
Component Pool 1 Pool 2
5X Q5 Reaction Buffer
dNTPs (10 mM each)
Q5 Hot Start DNA Polymerase
Primer Pool 1 or 2 (50 µM)
Nuclease-free water
Total

source.body: A PCR mastermix for each pool should be made up in the mastermix cabinet and aliquoted into PCR strip tubes. Tubes should be wiped down when entering and leaving the mastermix cabinet.

source.description:
In the extraction and sample addition cabinet add
diluted cDNA to each tube and mix well by pipetting.

source.body: The extraction and sample addition cabinet should should be cleaned with decontamination wipes and UV sterilised before and after use.

source.description: Pulse centrifuge the tubes to collect the contents at the bottom of the tube.

Set-up the following program on the thermal cycler:
Stage Temperature Time
Heat Activation
30 cycles* of ...
Denaturation
Annealing
**
Hold
Indefinite

source.body: *) We recommend 30 PCR cycles regardless of Ct-value because comparing PCR product yield and Ct-value gives a simple safeguard against sample swapping. However, one could increase this number to 35 to achieve more even PCR product yields.

**) Previously, 65 °C was used for the annealing/extension step in multiplex PCR. However, inspecting many results in different thermocyclers and institutes, we now consider setting this temperature to rather than 65 °C consistently yields better result with N1/N2 primer set. Nevertheless, fine-tuning of this temperature may still recommended to obtain the best result. Generally, amplicon 64 tends to show low coverage if annealing/extension temparature is higher than optimal.

source.description: Combine each 10 µl contents of “Pool 1” and “Pool 2” PCR reactions for each biological sample into to a new 8-strip PCR tubes or 96-well PCR plate.

Clean-up the amplicons using the AmpureXP using 1x volume.
Elute in
of low-TE buffer (10 mM tris-HCl pH8.0, 0.1 mM EDTA).
Transfer eluted DNA to a new 8-strip PCR tubes or 96-well PCR plate.

source.body: Amplicon clean-up should be performed in the post-PCR cabinet which should should be cleaned with decontamination wipes and UV sterilised before and after use.

source.description: Quantify the amplicon pools using fluorescent based method such as Qubit dsDNA HS kit (Invitrogen), Qaunt-it High-Sensitivity dsDNA Assay Kit (Invitrogen), or QuantiFluor® dsDNA System (Promega).
!!! We do not recommend normalizing library concentrations at this step but after adapter ligation. It is more immune to sample swapping. !!!

source.body: * In our experience, samples with DNA concentration less than in 30 cycles at this point do not generate meaningful results.
You can expect the quantity of DNA input will be directly proportional to the amount of data you will obtain if no further adjustment takes place.

source.body: This protocol uses 1/4 reagents per sample compared to the original QIAseq FX DNA library kit (Qiagen: 180473 for 24-plex, 180475 and 180477 for 96-plex, and 180479, 180480, 180481 and 180482 for 384-plex).
Make sure the plate is always during this procedure to avoid fragmentation reaction proceeds at this step.

source.description:
Remove the tube or plate from the thermal cycler after finishing the thermal program.
Take the adapter plate out of the kit box and thaw the content.
Add
adapter solution to each end-prepped DNA mixture.
Prepare a master mix per sample below.
Component Volume / sample
DNA Ligase Buffer, 5x
DNA Ligase

Start the thermal program, and place the tubes or plate immediately.

source.body: Keep both end-prepped DNA mixture and thawed adapter solution during this step.
Seal and store remaining adapter plate in -20 °C. Extreme care should be taken to avoid cross-contamination between different indexed adapters.

source.description:
Prepare a 1.5 or 2.0 ml low-binding tube.
Take
* ligated mixture from each well and pool them into the 1.5 or 2.0 ml low-binding tube.
Finaly, elute DNA in
low-TE or Elution Buffer.
Transfer the eluted DNA to a new 1.5 or 2.0 ml low-binding tube.
Purify again by Ampure XP using x1.2 volume.
Finaly, elute DNA in
low-TE or Elution Buffer.
Transfer the eluted DNA to a new 1.5 or 2.0 ml low-binding tube.

source.body: *You can take different volumes by sample to adjust the DNA quantities for even representation of each index See the (Guidelines & Warnings). Use the DNA concentrations measured after the PCR clean-up.

Now, the library is ready for sequencing after quantification.
You may use any your routine methods for library quantification.
We recommend qPCR based methods in terms of accuracy and sensitivity.
Here is our homemade protocol.
If you do not have a good quantification technique, here is a relationship between DNA mass concentration measured by Qubit dsDNA HS kit (Invitrogen) versus molar concentration measured by qPCR for nine libraries we obtained with this protocol.

source.description:
About N1/N2 primer set
Since March 2021, we have added another small modification on the N1 primer set (ver.
N2
). The modification is addition of one primer "nCoV-2019_72_RIGHT_C22A" to pool2 mixture. This primer contains an alternative nucleotide corresponding to G22017T mutation seen in
R.1 (B.1.1.316.1)
lineage to prevent amplicon 72 dropout.

description:
This protocol was originally folked from "ARTIC amplicon sequencing protocol for MinION for nCoV-2019" by Josh Quick to adapt for any illumina sequencers (iSeq, MiSeq, NextSeq, etc.).
Because the PCR products are fragmented and ligated with adapters, this protocol is compatible to many sequencing kits with various read lengths (75PE, 150PE, etc.) for Illumina machines.
While the library preparation uses QIAseq FX by Qiagen and is basically straight forward (as par kit instruction but modified to 1/4 scale), some tweaks for much of simplicity and speed were added.
Change histories (V2):
  1. The amount of cDNA input to multiplex PCR is increased (now almost same amount to the ARTIC Network's original protocol) (Step 10). This change gives better results for samples with extremely low RNA copy.
  2. Amount of adapter solution input was corrected (Step 19).
  4. Change histories (V3):
  5. RT step has been changed to use of LunaScript (Tyson et al., 2020).
  6. Corrected typos and wrong descriptions about amount of reagents.
  7. Added a link to library quantification protocol.
  8. Other minor changes.
  10. Change histries ( V4):
  11. Added description about the primer set ver. N1/N2.
  12. Added suggestion to double the concentration of nCoV-2019_74_LEFT and nCoV-2019_74_RIGHT.
  13. Default annealing & extension temperature of multiplex PCR was changed to 64 °C.
  14. Optional normalization step after PCR clean-up was omitted.
Change histories (V3):
  1. RT step has been changed to use of LunaScript (Tyson et al., 2020).
  2. Corrected typos and wrong descriptions about amount of reagents.
  3. Added a link to library quantification protocol.
  4. Other minor changes.
  6. Change histries ( V4):
  7. Added description about the primer set ver. N1/N2.
  8. Added suggestion to double the concentration of nCoV-2019_74_LEFT and nCoV-2019_74_RIGHT.
  9. Default annealing & extension temperature of multiplex PCR was changed to 64 °C.
  10. Optional normalization step after PCR clean-up was omitted.
Change histries ( V4):
  1. Added description about the primer set ver. N1/N2.
  2. Added suggestion to double the concentration of nCoV-2019_74_LEFT and nCoV-2019_74_RIGHT.
  3. Default annealing & extension temperature of multiplex PCR was changed to 64 °C.
  4. Optional normalization step after PCR clean-up was omitted.
